text:

A former official at Venezuela’s state oil company pleaded guilty in U.S. court to a money-laundering charge, admitting to taking bribes from American companies for business with the oil firm.
The ex-official, Cesar Rincon, is one of five men whom the U.S. has charged with conspiring to solicit bribes from U.S. businesses. The allegations are part of a larger, ongoing investigation of bribery at Petróleos de Venezuela SA, or PdVSA.
The five, known as the “management team,” sought payments to help companies win business from PdVSA, or to ensure money the oil company owed to the firms was paid, the U.S. Justice Department alleged. The men then allegedly laundered, and concealed, the proceeds of the scheme through a series of complex international financial transactions, prosecutors said.
A 20-count indictment against the “management team” members charged each person with at least one count of money laundering, and with conspiracy. Two face counts of conspiracy to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The FCPA bars the use of bribes to foreign officials to get or keep business.
Mr. Rincon, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit money laundering, also agreed to forfeit $7 million. He admitted to taking bribes from two men who have already pleaded guilty to violating the FCPA, as well as from owners of other energy companies in the U.S., the Justice Department said.
Sentencing is scheduled for July 9.
One of the remaining four defendants is in custody in the U.S. after being extradited from Spain, while two remain there pending extradition. A fourth person is at large, the Justice Department said. Lawyers for the men couldn’t immediately be identified.
The Justice Department has announced guilty pleas by 11 people, including Mr. Rincon, as part of the broader PdVSA investigation.
